{{TennisEventInfo|2009|Polska Energia Open| | date=June 15 – June 21 | edition=4th | location=[[Bytom]], [[Poland]] | champs={{flagicon|FRA}} [[Laurent Recouderc]] | champd={{flagicon|ESP}} [[Pablo Santos (tennis)|Pablo Santos]] / {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Gabriel Trujillo-Soler]] }}
The '''2009 [[Polska Energia Open]]''' was a professional [[tennis]] tournament played on [[Tennis court#Clay courts|outdoor red clay courts]]. It was part of the [[2009 ATP Challenger Tour]]. It took place in [[Bytom]], [[Poland]] between 15 and 21 June 2009.
==Singles entrants== ===Seeds=== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Nationality ! Player ! Ranking* ! Seeding |- | {{flag|FRA}} | [[Josselin Ouanna]] | 120 | 1 |- | {{flag|ESP}} | [[Rubén Ramírez Hidalgo]] | 123 | 2 |- | {{flag|ESP}} | [[Santiago Ventura Bertomeu|Santiago Ventura]] | 127 | 3 |- | {{flag|FRA}} | [[Laurent Recouderc]] | 142 | 4 |- | {{flag|ESP}} | [[Pablo Santos (tennis)|Pablo Santos]] | 181 | 5 |- | {{flag|CZE}} | [[Jan Hájek (tennis)|Jan Hájek]] | 201 | 6 |- | {{flag|SRB}} | [[Boris Pašanski]] | 213 | 7 |- | {{flag|ESP}} | [[Miguel Ángel López Jaén]] | 214 | 8 |} * Rankings are as of May 25, 2009.
===Other entrants=== The following players received wildcards into the singles main draw: * {{flagicon|POL}} [[Mateusz Kowalczyk]] * {{flagicon|POL}} [[Michał Przysiężny]] * {{flagicon|POL}} Mateusz Szmigiel * {{flagicon|POL}} Bojan Szumański
The following players received entry from the qualifying draw: * {{flagicon|CAN}} [[Vasek Pospisil]] * {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Guillaume Rufin]] * {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Artem Smirnov (tennis)|Artem Smirnov]] * {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Nicolás Todero]]
==Champions== ===Singles=== {{main|2009 Polska Energia Open – Singles}} {{flagicon|FRA}} '''[[Laurent Recouderc]]''' def. {{flagicon|CZE}} [[Jan Hájek (tennis)|Jan Hájek]], 6–3, 6–4
===Doubles=== {{main|2009 Polska Energia Open – Doubles}} {{flagicon|ESP}} '''[[Pablo Santos (tennis)|Pablo Santos]]''' / {{flagicon|ESP}} '''[[Gabriel Trujillo-Soler]]''' def. {{flagicon|CZE}} [[Jan Hájek (tennis)|Jan Hájek]] / {{flagicon|CZE}} [[Dušan Karol]], 6–3, 7–6(3)

revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | name = Accra Sports Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Ohene Djan stadium, Accra.jpg | caption = | fullname = | location = [[Accra]], [[Ghana]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1952 | renovated = 2007 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = [[Alexander Georgiev Barov]] | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 40,000{{cite web|title=Ohene Djan Stadium will last "forever"- Micheletti|url=http://www.ghananewsagency.org/details/Sports/Ohene-Djan-Stadium-will-last-forever--Micheletti/?ci=5&ai=3148|publisher=ghananewsagency.org|accessdate=4 December 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://stadiumdb.com/stadiums/gha/ohene_djan_sports_stadium|title=Accra Sports Stadium – StadiumDB.com|website=stadiumdb.com}} | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[Great Olympics]]
[[Accra Hearts of Oak SC|Hearts of Oak]] }} The '''Accra Sports Stadium''', formerly named the '''Ohene Djan Stadium''' is a multi-use, 39,800 all-seater [[stadium]] in [[Accra]].{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/africa/countries/ghana.shtml|title=World Stadiums - Stadiums Ghana|website=www.worldstadiums.com}} [[Ghana]], mostly used for [[association football]] matches. It is also used for rugby union.{{cite web|url=http://xliveafrica.com/2016/02/22/conquerors-blow-hurricanes-away-in-rugby-championship-final/|title=Conquerors blow Hurricanes away in Rugby Championship Final - X Live Africa|website=xliveafrica.com}} ==Overview== The stadium was inaugurated in 1952 by a football match played between Accra XI and Kumasi XI. Originally known as the Accra Sports Stadium, the stadium was renamed after Ohene Djan, the country's first Director of Sports, in 2004 after renovations. Its renaming was quite controversial and opposed by the Ga people.{{cite news |url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/SportsArchive/artikel.php?ID=80345 |title=Ohene Djan Did Not Warrant Honour - Adjin Tettey |accessdate=2007-04-06 |date=28 April 2005 |author=Ghanaian Chronicle |work=Sports news |publisher=Ghana Home Page}} There has been ongoing controversy about the name of the stadium. On June 16, 2011, the name 'Ohene Djan Stadium' on the stadium building was changed to 'Accra Sports Stadium' without any official announcement by the Accra Metropolitan Assembly supported by the National Democratic Congress Government.{{cite news |url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/SportsArchive/artikel.php?ID=211396 |title=Ohene Djan Stadium renamed Accra Sports Stadium |accessdate=2011-06-19 |date=2011-06-17 |publisher=Ghana Home Page }} It has since been reverted. As a designated venue of some of the [[2008 African Cup of Nations]] matches, the stadium was rebuilt, upgraded and modernized to meet [[FIFA]] standards. Work on the stadium was completed in October 2007. It was inaugurated with a four-nations tournament that Ghana won (the Zenith Cup). The stadium is also the home of one of Africa's most popular clubs, [[Accra Hearts of Oak SC|Hearts of Oak]] as well as [[Great Olympics]], but [[Ghana national football team|Ghana's national team]] matches are sometimes played there. During the [[2000 African Cup of Nations]] in [[Ghana]] and [[Nigeria]], the stadium hosted 9 matches,{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/static/sport/football/africa/cup_of_nations/accra.stm |title=Accra National Stadium |accessdate=2007-04-06 |work=Cup of Nations Venue Guide |publisher=BBC}} and was also the venue of the [[1978 African Cup of Nations|1978 final]]. ==See also== *[[Accra Sports Stadium disaster]] *[[Ghana national theatre]] *[[Accra International Conference Center]] ==Notes and references== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110726102412/http://www.ghana-pedia.org/org/index.php?option=com_directory&listing=Ohene%20Djan%20Sports%20Stadium&page=viewListing&lid=71&Itemid=36 Ghana-pedia webpage - Ohene Djan Sports Stadium] *[http://www.myjoyonline.com/archives/photos/2007/4854.asp New Work-in-Progress Photos - October 2007] *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/africa/ghana/accra_sports_stadium.shtml Photo] at [http://www.worldstadiums.com/ worldstadiums.com] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071012055336/http://fussballtempel.net/caf/GHA/Accra.html Photos] at [http://www.fussballtempel.net/ fussballtempel.net] *[http://www.morenomarrazzo.com/accra.htm Stadium design] Moreno Marrazzo {{coord|5|33|05.51|N|0|11|30.36|W|type:landmark|display=title}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = [[African Cup of Nations]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox sport
| name = Aerobic gymnastics | image = figuraaerobic.jpg | imagesize = 220px | caption = A sport aerobics team | union = [[Fédération Internationale de Gymnastique]] | first = United States, 1980's | firstlabel = First contested | country/region = Worldwide | registered = | clubs = | contact = Not with opponents | team = | mgender = Yes | category = Gymnastic sport | equipment = | venue = | obsolete = | olympic = No | paralympic = | IWGA = [[1993 World Games|1993]]{{snds}}[[2017 World Games|2017]] }}
'''Aerobic gymnastics''' or '''sport aerobics''' is a competitive sport originating from traditional [[aerobics]] in which complex, high-intensity movement patterns and elements of varying difficulty are performed to music.
==Nature of the game==
The performance area is {{convert|7|m}} square for juniors or {{convert|10|m}} square for adults and for aero dance and step.
In International competition there are 7 different events: Individual Women, Individual Men, Mixed Pairs, Trios, Group (five athletes), Step and Dance (both eight athletes). The last four are regardless of the Genders of the athletes.
The performances are made up of four groups of elements. The routine must be performed entirely to music.
In the competition, there are specific requirements regarding the outfit, the number of elements performed, the number of lifts performed, the number of elements performed on the floor and much more.
Performances are scored in the following areas: artistry, execution, difficulty and the chair of the judges panel determines the final score deductions based on deductions that change with each code of points. If the combined scores are the same, the tiebreaker is the team with higher execution scores.
The long-term ultimate goal of the sport of aerobic gymnastics is to be included in the Olympic Games.
==Competitive aerobic gymnastics==
=== FIG aerobics === The competitive aerobic gymnastics are governed by the [[Fédération Internationale de Gymnastique]] (FIG). The FIG designs the Code of Points and regulates all aspects of international elite competition. Within individual countries, gymnastics is regulated by national federations. In 1995, the FIG recognised sport aerobics as a new competitive gymnastics discipline, organised judges and coaches courses and launched the 1st [[Aerobic Gymnastics World Championships]] in Paris (34 countries). In 1997, the IWGA ([[International World Games Association]]) included Aerobic Gymnastics in its programme of the 5th [[World Games]] ([[Lahti]], [[Finland]]).<ref name=figHistory>[http://www.fig-gymnastics.com/vsite/vcontent/page/custom/0,8510,5187-188589-205811-44714-283047-custom-item,00.html Federation Internationale de Gymnastique] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090705113142/http://www.fig-gymnastics.com/vsite/vcontent/page/custom/0%2C8510%2C5187-188589-205811-44714-283047-custom-item%2C00.html |date=5 July 2009 }} History of Aerobic Gymnastics with the FIG: </ref> Since 1999 The European Union of Gymnastics has been conducting Aerobic European Gymnastics Championships in all uneven years.<ref name=UEG>[http://www.ueg-gymnastics.com/commstore/commstore2.pl/93fa6128715b50e9/en/default.html?k=88&block_id=head,P3,content&P1=47&P2=47&P3=disciplines&P4=5&P10=47&P9=88 European Union of Gymnastics]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} History of Aerobic Gymnastics</ref> Leading nations who have provided World Medallists are: [[Australia]], [[Brazil]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Chile]], [[China]], [[France]], [[Hungary]], [[Italy]], [[Japan]], [[Korea]], [[New Zealand]], [[Romania]], [[Russia]] and [[Spain]].<ref name = figHistory/>
=== National Aerobic Championships === The '''National Aerobic Championships''' is a competition of aerobic gymnastics started in 1984 in the United States. Founded by Sport Fitness International, it was the first major championships in the sport predating the [[Aerobic Gymnastics World Championships]] by 11 years. From 1988 onwards the individual events were separated by gender. The sport became popular around the world after it gained popularity in the USA when major championships were aired on ESPN during the height of the fitness movement in the USA.
== In Popular Culture == The sport was added in the biannual [[Idol Star Athletics Championships]] for Lunar New Year, 2017 as a male team equivalent to the female individual rhythmic gymnastics, and the scores are given in accordance to FIG Standards. [[Seventeen (band)|Seventeen]] (9.8 Technical+9.3 Execution-0.0 Penalty) and [[Astro (South Korean band)|ASTRO]] (9.75+9.45-0.1) both scored 19.10 out of 20.00, but since ASTRO scored higher in Execution, ASTRO won the inaugural event.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/kpop/comments/5qzllz/isac_idol_star_athletics_championships/|title=ISAC (Idol Star Athletics Championships) Performances and Results 2017 Seollal Special • r/kpop|website=reddit|language=en|access-date=31 July 2017}}</ref>
=== FISAF aerobics === The [[Federation of International Sports, Aerobics and Fitness]] (FISAF) is an international [[non-profit organization|non-profit]] "umbrella organization" active in over 40 countries. It is self-described as "the largest [[physical fitness|fitness]] industry organisation in the world" and "the largest instructor certification agency in the world".
==References== {{Portal|Gymnastics}} {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Aerobic gymnastics}} *[http://sportaerobics-nac.com The Association of National Aerobics Championships] (ANAC) http://www.fig-gymnastics.com/site/site/miniSiteNews?id=14712

{{other uses|Ballet shoes (disambiguation)}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[Image:Ballet shoes in fifth position.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Leather ballet shoes, with feet shown in [[Glossary of ballet#Positions of the feet|fifth position]]]] A '''ballet shoe''', or '''ballet slipper''', is a lightweight shoe designed specifically for ballet dancing. It may be made from soft leather, canvas, or satin, and has flexible, thin soles. Traditionally, women wear pink shoes and men wear white or black shoes. Tan colored slippers—which are unobtrusive and thus give the appearance of dancing barefoot—are worn in modern ballets and sometimes modern dancing by both men and women.
All dancers typically wear ballet slippers at the beginning of a ballet class, whereas female dancers may change into [[pointe shoes]] for centre work and performance.
Ballet shoes must fit very closely to the foot, for safety and to retain maximum flexibility.
==Construction== Ballet shoes traditionally have a leather sole which does not reach all the way to the edges of the shoe. A modern development is the split sole, which provides greater flexibility and emphasizes the shape of the foot when pointed. They are usually made from soft leather, canvas or satin. [[Leather]] shoes are long-lasting. [[Canvas]] shoes are less expensive but wear faster than average leather ballet shoes. [[Satin]] shoes are often used for performances but can wear out very quickly.
Shoes are secured with the use of [[Elastomer|elastic]], most often with a single band across the arch of the foot, or with two bands that cross in an "X" shape at the top of the arch. In the case of double band shoes, some ballet slipper manufacturers will attach one end of each band to the shoe as part of the production process, and leave it to the purchaser to attach the free ends of the bands for optimal fit.
== History == Women began to dance ballet in 1682, twenty years after King [[Louis XIV of France]] ordered the founding of the [[Paris_Opera#The_Opera_under_Louis_XIV|Royal Academy of Dance]]. At that time, the standard women's ballet shoe had [[heel (shoe)|heel]]s. Mid 18th century dancer [[Marie Camargo]] of the [[Paris Opéra Ballet]] was the first to wear a non-heeled shoe. After the [[French Revolution]], heels were completely eliminated from standard ballet shoes, as they still are.
==See also== *[[Pointe shoe]] *[[Footwear]] *[[Ballet]] *[[Ballet boot]] * [[List of shoe styles]]
{{Ballet}} {{Footwear}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ballet Shoes}} [[Category:Shoes]] [[Category:Dance shoes]] [[Category:Sports footwear]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Officeholder |name = Boma Iyaye |honorific-prefix = [[The Honorable]] |image = |office = Rivers State Commissioner of Sports |governor = [[Ezenwo Nyesom Wike]] |term_start = 18 December 2015 |term_end = |predecessor = Fred Mbombo Igwe |successor = |governor1 = [[Chibuike Amaechi]] |term_start1 = July 2009 |term_end1 = June 2011 |predecessor1 = Boma Iyaye |successor1 = Fred Mbombo Igwe |governor2 = [[Chibuike Amaechi]] |term_start2 = 4 April 2008 |term_end2 = 4 June 2009 |predecessor2 = Christopher Green |successor2 = Boma Iyaye |office3 = [[Rivers State House of Assembly|MHA]] for Ogu–Bolo |term_start3 = 2003 |term_end3 = 2007 |predecessor3 = Adokiye Oruwari |successor3 = Maureen Tamuno |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1969|9|24|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Ogu Town]], [[Ogu–Bolo]], [[Rivers State]], Nigeria |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Rivers State People's Democratic Party|PDP]] |spouse = Joy Iyaye |children = 3 |alma_mater = [[Rivers State University of Science and Technology]] |profession = [[Accountant]] }} '''Boma Iyaye''' (born 24 September 1969) is a Rivers State [[accountant]], politician and the incumbent Commissioner of Sports.<ref name="Today FM">{{cite news|author=|title=The Rivers State Commissioner Sports, Boma Iyaye has Constituted a six-man committee to re-organize the two State-owned professional football clubs, Sharks and Dolphins|url=http://www.todayfmlive.com/news/item/1258-the-rivers-state-commissioner-sports-boma-iyaye-has-constituted-a-six-man-committee-to-re-organize-the-two-state-owned-professional-football-clubs-sharks-and-dolphins.html|accessdate=21 September 2016|work=Today FM|via=|date=19 January 2016}}</ref>
==Education== He was educated at State School II [[Port Harcourt]] between 1974 and 1980. He attended [[Baptist High School]] for his [[secondary education]] from 1981 to 1986. A year later, he enrolled at the [[Rivers State University of Science and Technology]] and studied [[Accountancy]]. He thereafter completed the one-year mandatory [[National Youth Service Corps]] program.<ref name="Sports Ministry"/>
==Career== Iyaye began his career in the private sector as an [[accountant]]. He worked with several multinational companies between 1992 and 2003. Later he entered into politics and successfully ran for a seat in the [[Rivers State House of Assembly]], where he served until 2007 representing Ogu–Bolo. He was the Chairman of the House Committee on Sports as well as member of other sub-committees at the Assembly.<ref name="Sports Ministry"/>
In December 2015, he was inducted into the [[Wike Executive Council]] as the Commissioner of Sports. Iyaye had previously served in the same office from 4 April 2008 to 4 June 2009, and again from July 2009 to June 2011.<ref name="Sports Ministry">{{cite web|title=Bio-Data on Hon. Boma Iyaye - Commissioner for Sports, Rivers State |url=http://riversstate.gov.ng/government/a-z-list-of-mda-s/414-sports-ministry.html |accessdate=22 September 2016 |website=archive.org |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806083742/http://riversstate.gov.ng/government/a-z-list-of-mda-s/414-sports-ministry.html |archivedate=6 August 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Wike Exco}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox sportsperson | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | nationality = I-Kiribati | residence = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1984|7|17}} | birth_place = [[Nonouti]], [[Kiribati]] | height ={{height|m=1.66}} | weight ={{convert|104.58|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | website = | country = {{flagcountry|Kiribati}} | sport = [[Olympic weightlifting|Weightlifting]] | event = | collegeteam = | universityteam = | club = | team = | turnedpro = | partner = | former_partner = | coach = | retired = | coaching = | worlds = | regionals = | nationals = | olympics = | highestranking = | pb = | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry | {{KIR}} }} {{MedalCompetition|Oceania Weightlifting Championships}} {{MedalGold | 2007 Apia | 94 kg}} {{MedalGold | 2009 Darwin | 94 kg}} {{MedalGold | 2012 Apia | 94 kg}} {{MedalGold | 2013 Brisbane | 105 kg}} {{MedalGold | 2014 Mont Dore | 105 kg}} {{MedalGold | 2016 Suva | 105 kg}} {{MedalBronze | 2006 Apia | 85 kg}} {{MedalBronze | 2010 Suva | 94 kg}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Pacific Games]]}} {{MedalGold| [[Weightlifting at the 2015 Pacific Games|2015 Port Moresby]] | -105 kg}} {{MedalSilver| [[2007 South Pacific Games|2007 Apia]] | -85 kg}} {{MedalSilver| [[Weightlifting at the 2011 Pacific Games|2011 Nouméa]] | -94 kg}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Commonwealth Games]]}} {{MedalGold| [[Weightlifting at the 2014 Commonwealth Games|2014 Glasgow]] | 105 kg}} | show-medals = }} '''David Katoatau''' (born July 17, 1984) is an [[I-Kiribati]] [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifter]].
At the [[2007 World Weightlifting Championships]] he ranked 37th in the 85 kg category, with a total of 281 kg.<ref name="IWF results">{{cite web|title=KATOATAO David |publisher=International Weightlifting Federation |url=http://www.iwf.net/results/results_athlete_e.php?compid=1750 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110527163528/http://www.iwf.net/results/results_athlete_e.php?compid=1750 |archivedate=2011-05-27 |df= }}</ref>
He ranked 4th in the 85 kg category at the 2008 Oceania Weightlifting Championships, with a total of 292 kg.<ref name="IWF results" />
==Career== Katoatau represented [[Kiribati]] in [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifting]] at the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in [[Beijing]], [[China]],<ref>[http://solomonstarnews.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2153&change=100&changeown=102&Itemid=42 "Hale to Olympics"], ''Solomon Star'', July 14, 2008</ref> and also was the [[2008 Summer Olympics national flag bearers|national flag bearer]] at the opening ceremony.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_1344.pdf |title=List of Flagbearers Beijing 2008 |publisher=www.olympic.org |format=[[PDF]] |accessdate=2008-08-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080808093945/http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_1344.pdf |archivedate=2008-08-08 |df= }}</ref> In the Olympic tournament he ranked 15th in the 85 kg category, with a total of 313 kg.<ref>{{cite web|title=KATOATAU David |publisher=International Weightlifting Federation |url=http://www.iwf.net/results/results_athlete_e.php?compid=1926 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110527165518/http://www.iwf.net/results/results_athlete_e.php?compid=1926 |archivedate=2011-05-27 |df= }}</ref>
In 2012, he was the first I-Kiribati ever to qualify on merit for the Olympic Games (rather than receive a wildcard invitation), in any sport. He finished first in the Oceania Olympic Qualifying Tournament, which also made him Commonwealth champion.<ref>[http://www.sportingpulse.com/assoc_page.cgi?c=2-3848-0-0-0&news_task=DETAIL&articleID=19698623 "THE FIRST-EVER OLYMPIC QUALIFIER !"], Kiribati National Olympic Committee, June 2013</ref> As part of [[Kiribati at the 2012 Summer Olympics|Kiribati's delegation]] at the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in [[London]], he competed in the [[Weightlifting at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's 94 kg|94 kg event]], and finished 17th out of 21, with a total lift of 325 kg.<ref>[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ka/david-katoatau-1.html David Katoatau] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305225053/http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ka/david-katoatau-1.html |date=2016-03-05 }}. sports-reference.com</ref> He was, again, his country's national flag bearer during the Games' [[2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]].<ref>[http://www.olympic.org/Documents/Games_London_2012/Flagbearers.pdf List of flag bearers, 2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony], official website</ref>
At the 2014 Glasgow Commonwealth Games he won gold in the 105 kg group A, the first ever Commonwealth Games medal for Kiribati.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://results.glasgow2014.com/event/weightlifting/wlm005a01/mens_105kg_group_a.html|title=Glasgow 2014 - Men's 105kg Group A|work=glasgow2014.com|accessdate=26 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-sport/kataotau-wins-kiribatis-first-games-medal-20140731-3cv33.html|title=Katoatau the toast of Kiribati|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=26 May 2015}}</ref>
At the [[2016 Summer Olympics]], he became famous for his dance routines, which he did to bring awareness of the [[effects of global warming]] on his small island nation, upon completion of a clean & jerk lift.<ref>https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/08/david-katoatau-olympics-kiribati/496175/</ref><ref>{{YouTube|AK3eRt2e7TU|Weightlifter becomes crowd favorite with crazy dances'}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://time.com/4453753/david-katoatau-kiribati-olympics-climate-change/ |title=This Olympic Weightlifter Danced Off Stage to Raise Awareness of Climate Change |last1=Samuelson |first1=Kate |date=August 16, 2016 |website=time.com |publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |access-date=August 18, 2016 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2016/08/16/kiribati-weightlifters-joyful-dance-comes-with-a-serious-message/ |title=Kiribati weightlifter is dancing to save his island from climate change |last1=Boren |first1=Cindy |date=August 16, 2016 |website=washingtonpost.com |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=August 18, 2016 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/08/david-katoatau-olympics-kiribati/496175/ |title=The Saddest Olympic Celebration; What do you do when you’re competing for a country that might disappear? You dance. |last1=Friedman |first1=Uri |date=August 16, 2016 |website=theatlantic.com |publisher=[[The Atlantic]] |access-date=August 18, 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
==Achievements== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Year !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="2"|Snatch !colspan="2"|Clean & Jerk !rowspan="2"|Total !rowspan="2"|Rank |- !Result !Rank !Result !Rank |- |rowspan=3|David Katoatau ||[[Weightlifting at the 2008 Summer Olympics|2008]]||[[Weightlifting at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's 85 kg|85 kg]] ||135 kg ||18th ||178 kg ||15th ||313 kg ||15th |- |[[Weightlifting at the 2012 Summer Olympics|2012]]||[[Weightlifting at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's 94 kg|94 kg]] || 140 kg || 17th || 185 kg || 15th || 325 kg || 17th |- |[[Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics|2016]]||[[Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 105 kg|105 kg]] || 145 kg || 17th || 204 kg || 12th || 349 kg || 14th |}

'''Right center field:''' {{convert|375|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Right field:''' {{convert|330|ft|m|sp=us}} | acreage = | tenants = [[Illinois State Redbirds baseball]] (1988-present) }} '''Duffy Bass Field''' is a [[baseball]] venue in [[Normal, Illinois|Normal]], [[Illinois]], [[United States|USA]]. It is home to the [[Illinois State Redbirds baseball]] team of the [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[Missouri Valley Conference]]. It was built in 1988{{cite web |title=Duffy Bass Field |url=http://www.goredbirds.com/facilities/redbird-field.html |work=GoRedbirds.com |accessdate=26 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60TXqmuaZ?url=http://www.goredbirds.com/facilities/redbird-field.html |archivedate=2011-07-26 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and has a capacity of 1,200 spectators, 1,000 of which is seated. The field is also home to the University High School Pioneers baseball team.{{cite web |title=Baseball Stadium Renovation at Duffy Bass Field |url=http://www.goredbirds.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/ilsu-08-basebl-stadium-reconstruction.html |work=GoRedbirds.com |accessdate=26 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60TY4gUkj?url=http://www.goredbirds.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/ilsu-08-basebl-stadium-reconstruction.html |archivedate=2011-07-26 |deadurl=yes |df= }} == History == In both 1992 and 2003, the field was awarded the Professional Grounds Management Society's Honor Award for the excellent condition of its playing surface. Prior to 2008, the facility featured little seating and other amenities around the playing field. In 2006, however, a [[USD|$]]3.4 million renovation project was announced,{{cite web |last=Kindred |first=Randy |title=Kindred: Without Zenger, who can save stadium? |url=http://www.pantagraph.com/sports/college/football/article_a856cc60-187f-11e0-86c4-001cc4c002e0.html |work=Pantagraph.com |accessdate=26 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60TYSGyij?url=http://www.pantagraph.com/sports/college/football/article_a856cc60-187f-11e0-86c4-001cc4c002e0.html |archivedate=2011-07-26 |date=January 5, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and construction began on July 15, 2008. Part of then-athletic director Sheahon Zenger's initiative to improve Redbird athletic facilities, the project added 1,000 stadium seats, [[restroom]]s, concession stands, and ticket windows. It also upgraded the venue's [[press box]] and [[Dugout (baseball)|dugouts]]. An electronic scoreboard was added later.{{cite web|last=Warren |first=Jack |title=New scoreboard at ISU’s Duffy Bass Field |url=http://cornbeltbaseball.com/?p=8410 |work=Cornbelt Baseball |accessdate=26 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324090508/http://cornbeltbaseball.com/?p=8410 |archivedate=2012-03-24 |date=September 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Browning Day Mullins Dierdorff Architects designed the stadium structure,{{cite web|title=Duffy Bass Field Renovation Illinois State University |url=http://athleticbusiness.com/galleries/project.aspx?id=409 |work=Athletic Business |accessdate=26 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007092048/http://athleticbusiness.com/galleries/project.aspx?id=409 |archivedate=2011-10-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }} while McCoy Construction built the new facilities. In fall 2012, a [[FieldTurf]] infield was installed at the facility, while the outfield surface remained natural grass. Prior to the renovation, the field's surface had been entirely natural grass.{{cite web |title=Crews Begin Work on Duffy Bass Field Playing Surface |url=http://www.goredbirds.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/103012aaa.html |work=GoRedbirds.com |publisher=Illinois State Sports Information |accessdate=25 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CRlplxig?url=http://www.goredbirds.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/103012aaa.html |archivedate=25 November 2012 |date=30 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The '''2013 [[Missouri Valley Conference Baseball Tournament]]''' was held on May 21–25 2013 at Duffy Bass Field. == Naming == The field is named for former Illinois State baseball coach Duffy Bass. During Bass's 1964-1988 tenure, the Redbirds' record was 713-457-18. This record included a 1969 national championship in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association#Division history|College Division]] (the NCAA's now-defunct small school division).{{cite web|title=Horenberger/Bass Baseball Classic - History |url=http://www.iwusports.com/sports/2009/4/27/BB_0427094019.aspx?id=95 |work=IWU Sports |accessdate=26 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007054702/http://www.iwusports.com/sports/2009/4/27/BB_0427094019.aspx?id=95 |archivedate=2011-10-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Duffy Bass Field has been home to the Horenberger/Bass Baseball Classic, an annual game which commemorates Bass and [[Illinois Wesleyan University]]'s (in nearby [[Bloomington, Illinois|Bloomington]]) former baseball coach Jack Horenberger. First played in 2004, the game alternates between Duffy Bass and Illinois Wesleyan's Jack Horenberger Field. Illinois State has won four of six classics played. The game was rained out in 2009, 2011, and 2012.{{cite web|title=2011 Illinois Wesleyan Baseball Schedule |url=http://www.iwusports.com/schedule.aspx?path=baseball |work=IWU Sports |accessdate=26 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718060822/http://www.iwusports.com/schedule.aspx?path=baseball |archivedate=2011-07-18 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web |title=Horenberger-Bass Classic Game Canceled |url=http://www.goredbirds.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/050112aac.html |work=GoRedbirds.com |publisher=Illinois State Sports Information |accessdate=25 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CRlWguzV?url=http://www.goredbirds.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/050112aac.html |archivedate=25 November 2012 |date=1 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} == See also == * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] == References == {{Illinois State University}} {{Missouri Valley Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{Illinois NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Sports venues in Bloomington–Normal]] [[Category:Illinois State Redbirds baseball]] [[Category:1988 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1988]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Edge II Ice Arena | nickname = | image = EdgeIceArena centericeshot.jpg | image_size = 200px | location = 735 East Jefferson Street
[[Bensenville, Illinois]] 60106 | broke_ground = April 1997{{cite news |title=New Ice Arena Puts Bensenville On Cutting Edge|author=Jeff Coen|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1997-09-18/news/9709180138_1_ice-rink-ice-time-ice-surface|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=September 18, 1997|accessdate=November 19, 2011}} | built = | opened = October 1, 1997 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Village of Bensenville | operator = Village of Bensenville | surface = Two 200' x 85', One 200' x 90' | construction_cost= $2.1 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|2100000|1997}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Chicago Blackhawks]] ([[National Hockey League|NHL]]) (''practice facility'')
Chiefs Hockey Club ([[Youth Hockey]])
Chicago Blues([[Youth Hockey]])
[[Chicago Steel]] ([[United States Hockey League|USHL]]) (2000–2015)
[[Robert Morris Eagles]] ([[American Collegiate Hockey Association|ACHA]]) | seating_capacity = 3,000 (hockey) }} '''The Edge Ice Arena''' includes ''The Edge on John Street'', ''The Water's Edge Aquatic Center'', and The ''Edge II Ice Arena'' a 3,000-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] located in [[Bensenville, Illinois]]. It had been used as the official training facility and practice arena for the [[Chicago Blackhawks]] of the [[National Hockey League]] before the team built a new downtown Chicago training facility. The arena also had been used by [[Chicago Steel]] ([[United States Hockey League|USHL]]) from 2000-2015. The ice arena is also the home to the [[Robert Morris University Illinois|Robert Morris University Eagles]] Men's and Women's [[college ice hockey]] teams competing at the [[American Collegiate Hockey Association|ACHA]] DI level. The Edge is also home to several local high school ice hockey teams, and is used by local figure skating clubs, youth, and adult rec. ice hockey leagues (the Chicago Blues), as well as public skating. ==Facilities== The Edge on John Street has one 200' x 90' ice sheet. It is adjoined to The Water's Edge Aquatic Center, which includes an indoor 8-lane lap pool and 12' deep diving well. The Edge II Ice Arena has two [[NHL]] regulation-sized ice sheets. The main sheet of ice seats 2,800 fans in addition to nine luxury Sky Suites and an Executive Club Level seating area. ==Special Events== * The Edge II has been the host of four [[American Collegiate Hockey Association]] Men's Division I National Championship Tournaments in 2005, 2010, 2013 and 2016.http://www.achahockey.org/page.php?page_id=18410&league_id=1059 * The Edge II has been the host of one [[American Collegiate Hockey Association]] Women's Division I & Division II National Championship Tournament in 2008. * In April 2010 the facility hosted the 2010 High School Hockey National Championship Tournament.http://www.yournorthhills.com/northhillsnews/article/titans-shine-national-spotlight-lynch-scores-seven-goals-elimination-round * In April 2010 the facility also hosted "Ice Dreams", a 2-hour skating spectacular presented by Cuties and hosted by Dorothy Hamill. The show featured skating talent like Johnny Weir, Rachel Flatt and many more. * The wagon wheel skating club held their annual skating competition event here from September 11–13, 2015 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.bensenville.il.us/114/The-Edge-Ice-Arenas Edge Ice Arenas] {{USHL Arenas}} {{CSCHL}} {{Coord|41|56|48|N|87|55|32|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:College ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Illinois|Edge Ice Arena, The]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Robert Morris Eagles]] [[Category:1997 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1997]] {{Illinois-sports-venue-stub}}

It features three [[football (soccer)|football]] pitches, an [[ice rink]], an [[arena]], [[shooting range]] and [[tennis court]]s. On the second floor it also has a [[movie theatre|cinema]]. == Concerts == Egilshöllin has also been used as a [[music venue]] hosting numerous events of the [[Iceland Symphony Orchestra]] amongst others. {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Infobox stadium | name = FC Minsk Stadium | nickname = | image = Стадион ФК Минск.jpg | image_size = 270px | fullname = | location = [[Minsk]], [[Belarus]] | coordinates = {{Coord|53|51|42|N|27|34|43|E|display=inline|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = | built = 2012–2015 | opened = 2015 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | surface = Artificial grass | tenants = [[FC Minsk]]
[[FC Minsk (women)]] | capacity = 3,000 }} '''FC Minsk Stadium''' is a [[Association football|football]] stadium in [[Minsk]], [[Belarus]]. It is a home ground of [[FC Minsk]]. The stadium holds 3,000 people. == History == The stadium was built at the same location as former '''Kamvolschik Stadium''', which was most recently used for lower leagues, youth and reserve teams matches. By mid-2000s it had been largely abandoned and was slowly decaying. In the past, the stadium was used for [[Belarusian SSR]] league games and as an occasional substitute pitch for [[Belarusian Premier League]] and [[Belarusian Cup]] games by various clubs.[http://www.sb.by/sport/article/bylem-poroslo.html Abandoned stadiums in Minsk] == Modern use == In 2011 Kamvolschik Stadium was demolished. The new '''FC Minsk Stadium''' was built between 2012 and 2015[http://www.pressball.by/pbonline/football/78272 FC Minsk building new stadium] and opened in May 2015. Since then it was used primarily as a home venue by [[FC Minsk]], as well as their [[FC Minsk (women)|women's team]]. Additionally, the stadium hosted [[FC Minsk (women)|FC Minsk women's team]] [[UEFA Women's Champions League]] home maches as well as [[UEFA Youth League]] matches by FC Minsk youth squad. {{Coord|53|51|42|N|27|34|43|E|display=t|type:landmark}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.pressball.by/footballstat/stadiums/28/ Stadium profile at pressball.by] *[http://www.fcminsk.by/uslugi/iskusstvennoe-pole-na-mayakovskogo-1273.html Stadium profile at FC Minsk website] [[Category:Football venues in Belarus]] [[Category:Sport in Minsk]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Minsk]] {{Belarus-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox Olympic event |event = Women's halfpipe |games = 2018 Winter |image = Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg |image_size = 50px |caption = |venue = [[Bogwang Phoenix Park]], [[Pyeongchang County|Pyeongchang]], [[South Korea]] |dates = 19 February (qualification)
20 February (final) |competitors = 24 |nations = 13 |win_value = 95.80 |win_label = Winning score |gold = [[Cassie Sharpe]] |goldNOC = CAN |silver = [[Marie Martinod]] |silverNOC = FRA |bronze = [[Brita Sigourney]] |bronzeNOC = USA |prev = [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's halfpipe|2014]] |next = [[Freestyle skiing at the 2022 Winter Olympics – Women's halfpipe|2022]] }} {{Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics}} The '''Women's halfpipe''' event in '''[[freestyle skiing]]''' at the '''[[2018 Winter Olympics]]''' took place on 19 and 20 February 2018 at the [[Bogwang Phoenix Park]], [[Pyeongchang County|Pyeongchang]], [[South Korea]].{{cite web |url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/schedule|title=Schedule |publisher=[[POCOG]] |accessdate=13 January 2018}}[http://data.fis-ski.com/pdf/2018/FS/8058/2018FS8058SLQ1.pdf Start list] ==Qualification== {{main|Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Qualification}} The top 30 athletes in the Olympic quota allocation list qualified, with a maximum of four athletes per [[National Olympic Committee]] (NOC) allowed. All athletes qualifying must also have placed in the top 30 of a FIS World Cup event or the [[FIS Freestyle Ski and Snowboarding World Championships 2017]] during the qualification period (July 1, 2016 to January 21, 2018) and also have a minimum of 50 FIS points to compete. If the host country, [[South Korea at the 2018 Winter Olympics]] did not qualify, their chosen athlete would displace the last qualified athlete, granted all qualification criteria were met.{{cite web|url=https://data.fis-ski.com/media/olympic-games/2018/english-qs/owg-pyeongchang-2018-qualification-system-freestyle-skiing.pdf|title=Qualification Systems for XXII Olympic Winter Games, PyeongChang 2018 Freestyle skiing|date=9 September 2016|publisher=[[International Ski Federation]] (FIS)|accessdate=21 January 2018}} ==Results== ===Qualification=== The qualification was held on 19 February at 10:00.[http://data.fis-ski.com/pdf/2018/FS/8058/2018FS8058RLQ.pdf Qualification results] {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center" !Rank !! {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Use British English|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox cricketer | name = John Bryant | image = | country = England | fullname = John Bryant | nickname = | birth_date = 1717 | birth_place = Kent, England | death_date = {{death date|1772|7|23|df=yes}} | death_place = Bromley, Kent, England | batting = unknown hand | bowling = unknown style | role = batsman | club1 = [[Bromley Cricket Club|Bromley]] | year1 = c.1736 to 1756 | club2 = [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] | year2 = c.1736 to 1756 | date = 19 December | year = 2009 | columns = 0 | source = F. S. Ashley-Cooper }}
'''John Bryant''' (born c. 1717, probably at [[Bromley]], [[Kent]]; died 23 July 1772, probably at Bromley) was an English [[professionalism|professional]] [[cricket]]er who played in top-class matches through the 1740s and 1750s. He was mainly associated with [[Bromley Cricket Club]] and [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]]. Although information about his career is limited by a lack of surviving data, he is known to have made nineteen [[single wicket cricket|single wicket]] and thirteen [[first-class cricket|first-class]] appearances between 1743 and 1756. His brother was [[James Bryant (Kent cricketer)|James Bryant]].
==Earliest mentions== The first definite mention of John Bryant is in the single wicket "threes" match at the Artillery Ground on Monday, 11 July 1743. The six players involved were stated by the ''London Evening Post'' to be "the best in England".<ref name="ASW">Ashley-Cooper</ref> They were [[William Hodsoll]], [[John Cutbush (cricketer)|John Cutbush]] and [[Val Romney]] playing as Three of Kent; and [[Richard Newland (cricketer)|Richard Newland]], [[William Sawyer (cricketer)|William Sawyer]] and John Bryant playing as Three of [[All-England Eleven|All-England]]. Hodsoll and Newland were the captains. Kent won by 2 runs. The crowd was "computed" (''sic'') to be 10,000. A return match was arranged at [[Sevenoaks Vine]] on Wednesday, 27 July, but it did not come off.<ref name="ASW"/>
==Cricket career== During the next three seasons, the Bryants were regularly involved in top-class matches, both first-class and single wicket. In 1747, they played for Kent against [[Non-international England cricket teams|All-England]] in the biggest match of the season.<ref name="ASW"/> In early August 1747, there were two single wicket matches at the Artillery Ground which were organised by the [[Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond|2nd Duke of Richmond]]. In the first, three of his employees [[Stephen Dingate]], [[Joseph Rudd]] and [[Pye (Sussex cricketer)|Pye]] defeated [[Little Bennett]], [[Tall Bennett]] and [[William Anderson (18th-century cricketer)|William Anderson]]. In the second, the same threes were to play again but in a "fives" match with the two Bryants added to the Duke's team and with [[Tom Faulkner]] and one of [[Joe Harris (cricketer)|Joe]] or [[Joe Harris (cricketer)|John Harris]] to their opponents. The result of the second game is unknown.<ref>McCann, p.41.</ref>
1748 was the great year of single wicket, which has never been more popular before or since. There were five matches in which both Bryants took part and one which featured John only.<ref>From Lads to Lord's – 1748.</ref>
In 1749, the brothers were "given men" playing for [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] against All-England and then both played for Colchin's invitation XI against [[Stephen Dingate]]'s team.<ref name="ASW"/> There was a tri-series of matches between Kent and Surrey in 1750 with the brothers both playing for Kent, who won the first and third matches of the series, the decider by 1 wicket. Later in the season, they played for [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] as given men against [[Addington Cricket Club|Addington]], Dartford winning the match by 6 runs, and then for Dingate's "fives" team in a tri-series against [[Tom Faulkner]]'s side.<ref name="ASW"/>
James Bryant made his last known appearances in 1751 while John continued until 1756. He is not known to have played for Bromley again and the later mentions of him are as a given man for both Dartford and [[London Cricket Club|London]]. He was last recorded on Monday, 6 September 1756 playing for Darford against London at the Artillery Ground.<ref>Waghorn, p.31.</ref> He died on 23 July 1772.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010153248/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1741.html#bryant |date=10 October 2012 |title=From Lads to Lord's – James and John Bryant }}
==Bibliography== * [[F. S. Ashley-Cooper]], ''At the Sign of the Wicket: Cricket 1742–1751'', Cricket Magazine, 1900 * [[G. B. Buckley]], ''Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket'', Cotterell, 1935 * [[Timothy J. McCann]], ''Sussex Cricket in the Eighteenth Century'', Sussex Record Society, 2004 * [[H. T. Waghorn]], ''The Dawn of Cricket'', Electric Press, 1906
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bryant, John}} [[Category:English cricketers]] [[Category:English cricketers of 1701 to 1786]] [[Category:Kent cricketers]] [[Category:1717 births]] [[Category:1772 deaths]] [[Category:Non-international England cricketers]]
