revision.comment: Robot - Moving category 1980 Winter Olympics venues to [[:Category:Venues of the 1980 Winter Olympics]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 19]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name = Mt. Van Hoevenberg Olympic Bobsled Run | nrhp_type = | image = File BobsleighrunLP.JPG | caption = 2005 aerial view of the current bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton track | location = 220 Bob Sled Run, vicinity of [[Lake Placid, New York]] | coordinates = {{coord|44.220222|-73.921337|region:US_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = New York | area = {{convert|23|acre}} | built = | architect = | architecture = | added = February 4, 2010{{cite web |url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/listings/20100219.htm |title=Announcements and actions on properties for the National Register of Historic Places for February 19, 2010 |date=February 19, 2010 |accessdate=2010-05-16 |work=Weekly Listings |publisher=[[National Park Service]]}} | governing_body = Private | refnum = 10000008 }} The '''Mt. Van Hoevenberg Olympic Bobsled Run''' is a venue for [[bobsleigh]], [[luge]] and [[skeleton (sport)|skeleton]] located at the [[Lake Placid Olympic Sports Complex]] in [[Lake Placid, New York]], [[United States]]. This venue was used for the [[1932 Winter Olympics|1932]] and [[1980 Winter Olympics]] and for the only winter [[Goodwill Games]] in 2000. The third and most recent version of the track was completed in 2000 with the track hosting both the first [[FIBT World Championships]] and [[FIL World Luge Championships]] done outside of Europe, doing so in [[FIBT World Championships 1949|1949]][http://sports123.com/bob/mw-2.html Bobsleigh two-man world championship medalists since 1931] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929091333/http://sports123.com/bob/mw-2.html |date=2007-09-29 }} and [[FIL World Luge Championships 1983|1983]].[http://sports123.com/lug/mw-s.html FIL World Luge Championships men's single results since 1955] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071218194001/http://sports123.com/lug/mw-s.html |date=2007-12-18 }} In 2010 the bobsled track was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. == History == [[File:Olympic Bobsled Run Lake Placid2.jpg|thumb|[[Works Progress Administration]] poster from the late 1930s to advertise public access to the [[bobsled]] run from the [[1932 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lake Placid, New York]]]] The bobsled track was built in 1930.{{cite web |title=National Register of Historic Places Registration: Mt. Van Hoevenberg Olympic Bobsled Run |url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/feature/weekly_features/OlympicBobsledRun.pdf |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]] |date=January 2009 |author=Kathleen LaFrank and Philip G. Wolf|publisher=[[National Park Service]] |accessdate=2010-05-16}} (46 pages, with maps and 10 photos from 2007) According to the National Park Service:
Carved out of wilderness and surrounded by forested land on all sides, the one and one-half mile long Olympic Bobsled Run was constructed in 1930 and built specifically for the 1932 Winter Olympic Games. The course was designed by Stanislaus Sentzytsky, a renowned German course designer, who designed a course that was radically different from its European counterparts. The Lake Placid course was longer, steeper, and featured a more pronounced drop in curves than European runs, which allowed for steadier driving and faster speeds than those obtained on prior bobsled events. After the American team won two gold medals and one silver in 1932, bobsledding, previously unknown in America, captivated the country’s interest, and U.S. teams dominated the sport until 1956. Although portions of the course have been retired, parts of the original Olympic Bobsled Run continue to be used for training and recreation.{{cite web|title=Weekly Highlight 19 February 2010 Mt. Van Hoevenberg Olympic Bobsled Run, Essex County, New York | url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/feature/weekly_features/10_02_19_OlympicBobsledRun.htm}}
As Mt. Van Hoevenberg Olympic Bobsled Run, the structure was listed on the U.S. [[National Register of Historic Places]] on February 4, 2010. The listing was announced as the featured listing in the [[National Park Service]]'s weekly list of February 19, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/nrlist.htm |title=Weekly List Actions |accessdate=2010-05-16 |work= |publisher=National Park Service}} Prior to the [[1932 Winter Olympics]], bobsleigh racing took place at the steep hill where the Intervales [[ski jumping|ski jump]] would eventually be located.[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1932/1932w.pdf 1932 Winter Olympic Games official report.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080410085042/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1932/1932w.pdf |date=2008-04-10 }} pp. 30, 39-41, 50-1, 157-66. The attendees were delighted by the speeds of the [[bobsled]]s though several teams crashed during the run, sending two members of one team to the hospital as a result. The Intervales track only lasted one season (1929–30). Led by [[Henry Homburger]], the first track was surveyed and constructed during 1929-30 at [[Mount Van Hoevenberg]], located in the [[Whiteface Mountain]] area though it was in spite of protests of using state-owned lands for construction of the facility for environmental reasons. After construction took place during August–December 1930, the track opened for use on [[Christmas]] Day 1930. This track was {{convert|2366|m|ft}} long with 26 curves with a vertical drop of {{convert|228|m|ft}}, and an average grade of 9.6%. After the 1932 games, the first {{convert|829|m|ft}} and ten curves of the track were eliminated, shortening the track's length to {{convert|1537|ft}} with 16 curves, and an average grade of 9.3%.[http://www.bunksplace.com/hot%20runnings.html Bunksplace.com information on bobsleigh history: 1890-present.] - Accessed 15 January 2008. In 1949, the track became the first venue outside of Europe to host the [[FIBT World Championships]] though it would start with tragic results when [[Belgium|Belgian]] bobsledder [[Max Houben]] was killed during a practice run off of "Shady" curve prior to the event.[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,853670-1,00.html ''TIME'' magazine 7 March 1949 article about the Lake Placid, NY bobsleigh track that took Houbon's life] - Accessed 29 July 2007. The Belgian team withdrew as a result. It would be another [[FIBT World Championships 1961|twelve years]] before the track hosted another world championship following safety improvements to the track. By this time, track officials had established a relationship with the [[International Bobsleigh and Tobogganing Federation]] ([[FIBT]]).[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1980/orw1980v1.pdf 1980 Winter Olympic Games official report - Volume 1.] pp. 57-66. {{en icon}} & {{fr icon}} [[Sergio Zardini]]'s fatal crash at the "Zig-Zag curves" on 22 February 1966 would lead to further safety improvements.[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,835216,00.html "The Deadly Zig-Zag". ''TIME''. 4 March 1966] - Accessed August 12, 2007. Following the [[FIBT World Championships|world bobsleigh championships]] of [[FIBT World Championships 1969|1969]], [[FIBT World Championships 1973|1973]], and [[FIBT World Championships 1978|1978]], many race officials of those championships would serve on the organizing committee for the [[Bobsleigh at the 1980 Winter Olympics|bobsleigh part]] of the [[1980 Winter Olympics]]. In 1978 actual construction took place during September 1978-February 1979 with the creation of a [[reinforced concrete]], artificially [[refrigeration|refrigerated]] bobsleigh track. The bobsleigh track was approved for competition in December 1979. In fall 1977, a separate [[Luge at the 1980 Winter Olympics|luge track for the 1980 Games]], the first one in the [[United States]], was constructed with completion in time for the test competition in February 1979. During preparations for the 1980 Games, a combined two-man bobsleigh and luge track was considered, but abandoned to high cost and the track was redesigned with permission from the [[International Luge Federation]] (FIL). Following the 1980 games, both tracks hosted their respective [[FIBT World Championships 1983|world championships]] in [[FIL World Luge Championships 1983|1983]]. The 1932 track continued to be used strictly for passenger riding after the new combined track was sanctioned. Skeleton racing debuted during the 1990s with the bobsleigh part of the track hosting the world championships in [[FIBT World Championships 1997|1997]].[http://sports123.com/ske/mw.html FIBT men's skeleton world championships results since 1989] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929111059/http://sports123.com/ske/mw.html |date=2007-09-29 }} By the late 1990s, parts of both tracks were demolished to make way for a new track that was constructed for the 2000 Winter Goodwill Games that was completed in January 2000.[http://www.goodwillgames.com/2000/2000_venuesMtVanHoev.html List of venues on Mt. Van Hoevenberg for the 2000 Winter Goodwill Games] - Accessed 16 January 2008. The track has been part of the [[Lake Placid Olympic Sports Complex]] since the end of the 1980 Winter Olympics as part of the [[Olympic Regional Development Authority]] (ORDA).[http://www.orda.org/newsite/about.php About ORDA.][http://www.orda.org/newsite/togo/olympicsportscomplex.php ORDA profile on Lake Placid Olympic Sports Park.] Since 2006, it has hosted the [[Chevrolet|Chevy]] [[Geoff Bodine]] Bobsled Challenge, an annual event which has [[NASCAR]] drivers take a run down the track to benefit the [[Bo-Dyn Bobsled Project]] (co-created by the former NASCAR driver and [[1986 Daytona 500]] winner) in use by the United States since the start of the [[1994 Winter Olympics]].[http://www.bodynbobsled.com/ Bo-Dyn Bobsled Project official website] In 2009, the competition took place between NASCAR and the [[National Hot Rod Association]] (NHRA) which was won by [[Jeg Coughlin Jr.]] (NHRA) won the event. The 2010 event took place at the track 8–10 January with [[Melanie Troxel]] on the NHRA becoming the first woman to competes in the event. In 2009, the track became the first to host bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton world championships in the same year in a non-Winter Olympic year (The [[Utah Olympic Park bobsleigh/luge/skeleton track|bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton track]] in [[Park City, Utah]] was the first to do so for the [[2002 Winter Olympics]] in neighboring [[Salt Lake City]]).[http://www.whiteface.com/facilities/osc_bob.php Whiteface.com information about the track.] - accessed 3 December 2009. == Current track statistics== {|class="wikitable" |+Physical statistics ! Sport ! Length (meters) ! Turns ! Reason named |- | 4 | Eyrle | - |- | 10 | Whiteface | After [[Whiteface Mountain]] of the [[Adirondack Mountains]] of [[New York (state)|New York]]. |- | 14 | Cliffside | Because the track was located alongside a [[cliff]]. |- | 19 | Shady Corner | The corner was in the shadows even when the rest of the track was shining. |- | 23

25 | Zig-Zag | [[Labyrinth]] curve (three quick curves in succession) in the shape of an [[S]]. |} The bobsleigh track used for the [[1980 Winter Olympics]] consisted of 16 curves that was {{convert|1557|m|ft}} long with an elevation difference of {{convert|148|m|ft}}, a maximum grade of 14.0%, and an average grade of 9.5%.[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1980/orw1980v2.pdf 1980 Winter Olympic Games official report - Volume 2], pp. 49, 171, 177. {{en icon}}, {{fr icon}}, & {{de icon}} The luge track used for the 1980 Winter Olympics had two different settings to the different start houses used during the competition. For the men's singles event, the track consisted of 14 curves that was {{convert|1014|m|ft}} long with an elevation difference of {{convert|95.55|m|ft}}, a maximum gradient of 30% and an average grade of 9.35%. In the women's singles and men's doubles event, the track consisted of 11 curves that was {{convert|749|m|ft}} long with an elevation difference of {{convert|59|m|ft}}, a maximum grade of 30%, and an average grade of 9.35%. == Championships hosted == * [[Winter Olympics]]: [[1932 Winter Olympics|1932]], [[1980 Winter Olympics|1980]] * [[FIBT World Championships]]: [[FIBT World Championships 1949|1949]], [[FIBT World Championships 1961|1961]], [[FIBT World Championships 1969|1969]], [[FIBT World Championships 1973|1973]], [[FIBT World Championships 1978|1978]], [[FIBT World Championships 1983|1983]], [[FIBT World Championships 1997|1997]] (men's skeleton), [[FIBT World Championships 2003|2003]] (Men's bobsleigh), [[FIBT World Championships 2009|2009]], [[FIBT World Championships 2012|2012]] * [[FIL World Luge Championships]]: [[FIL World Luge Championships 1983|1983]], [[FIL World Luge Championships 2009|2009]] == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.whiteface.com/facilities/olympic-sports-complex Official website] {{Bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton tracks}} {{1932 Winter Olympics venues}} {{1980 Winter Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues bobsleigh}} {{Olympic venues luge}} {{National Register of Historic Places in New York}} {{National Register of Historic Places}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lake Placid Bobsleigh, Luge, And Skeleton Track}} [[Category:Venues of the 1932 Winter Olympics]] [[Category:Venues of the 1980 Winter Olympics]] [[Category:Bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton tracks]] [[Category:Olympic bobsleigh venues]] [[Category:Olympic luge venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues on the National Register of Historic Places in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues in Essex County, New York]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Essex County, New York]] [[Category:1930 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1930]]

They are currently competing in the [[Serbian basketball league system|4th-tier]] [[Second Regional Basketball League (Serbia)|Second Regional League, West Division]]. ==History== {{Empty section|date=May 2018}} ==Players== {{also|Category:OKK Šabac players}} == Coaches == {{also|Category:OKK Šabac coaches}} * {{flagicon|YUG}} [[Milovan Stepandić]] (1980–1989) ==Trophies and awards== ===Trophies=== *'''[[First Regional Basketball League (Serbia)|First Regional League]]''' ([[Serbian basketball league system|3rd-tier]]) ** '''Winner (2)''': [[2010–11 Serbian First League (basketball)|2010–11]], 2012–13 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://basketball.eurobasket.com/team/Serbia/OKK-Sabac/174 Profile] on eurobasket.com * [http://www.srbijasport.net/klub/4196-sabac/rez Profile] on srbijasport.net {{Men's Basketball Teams in Serbia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sabac, OKK}} [[Category:Basketball teams in Serbia|Sabac]] [[Category:Basketball teams in Yugoslavia|Sabac]] [[Category:Sport in Šabac]] {{Europe-basketball-team-stub}} {{Serbia-sport-stub}}

'''Performance Medicine''' is a sub-speciality of [[Clinical medicine|clinical]] and [[diagnostic medicine]] that is focussed on the optimisation of emotional, mental, and emotional well-being and performance. It is a new and innovative medical speciality that merges the goals of internal medicine, anti-ageing medicine, functional medicine, sports medicine and preventative health care.
Performance medicine differs fundamentally from other areas of medicine by focusing on the healthy non-injured individual that is at low risk of sub-clinical or clinical disease. This population of individuals responds poorly to the current medical paradigm<ref>M. Roy, M. Levasseur, Y. Couturier, B. Lindström, and M. Généreux, “The relevance of positive approaches to health for patient-centered care medicine,” Preventive Medicine Reports, vol. 2, pp. 10–12, Jan. 2015.</ref>. It uses the principles of evidence-based medicine not to treat disease, but optimise function to reacher higher levels of well-being and performance<ref>B. S. McEWEN, “Stress, Adaptation, and Disease: Allostasis and Allostatic Load,” Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences, vol. 840, no. 1, pp. 33–44, Feb. 2006.</ref>. This is the medical analog to the field of [[Positive psychology|positive psychology]], which uses the scientific principles of psychology not to treat mental disease, but to increase life satisfaction.
The aims of Performance medicine are to increase the bodies ability to resist, postpone or prevent disease and/or injury.<ref>[[Preventive medicine]]</ref> and maximise human performance in terms of adaptive capacity, endurance,<ref>[[Endurance]]</ref> and physical fitness,<ref>[[Physical fitness]]</ref>. Performance medicine physicians aim to measure the capacity and interaction of the bodies functional systems over time and to modify exposure to environmental factors in such a way that an individuals health is optimised by operating at the "sweet spot" where both performance and longevity are maximimised. This is achieved through an increased [[adaptive capacity]], which is the bodies ability to turn [[stressors]] into growth opportunities.
'''The goals of performance medicine have been summarised and include the following: ''' # a focus on maintaining and increasing an individuals adaptive capacity throughout adult life # the maximisation of an individuals [[Metabolic pathway|metabolic efficiency]] # the adoption of strategies that increase an individuals resistance to disease and postpone or [[Preventive medicine|prevent disease]] where possible
== Improving Well-Being == An organisms adaptive capacity determines its ability to adapt to new stressors<ref>B. S. McEwen, “Chapter 5 - Central Role of the Brain in Stress and Adaptation: Allostasis, Biological Embedding, and Cumulative Change,” in Stress: Concepts, Cognition, Emotion, and Behavior, G. Fink, Ed. San Diego: Academic Press, 2016, pp. 39–55.</ref><ref>McEwen BS, “Allostasis and the epigenetics of brain and body health over the life course: The brain on stress,” JAMA Psychiatry, vol. 74, no. 6, pp. 551–552, Jun. 2017.</ref>. Performance Medicine aims to increase an individuals adaptive capacity via functional improvements of the immune system, nervous system, hormonal system, and digestive system<ref>B. S. Oken, I. Chamine, and W. Wakeland, “A systems approach to stress, stressors and resilience in humans,” Behavioural Brain Research, vol. 282, pp. 144–154, Apr. 2015.</ref>. This increase adaptive capacity increases the ability of the individual to deal with stressors and thereby increases life satisfaction, as well as emotional, mental and physical functioning<ref>P. B. Badcock, C. G. Davey, S. Whittle, N. B. Allen, and K. J. Friston, “The Depressed Brain: An Evolutionary Systems Theory,” Trends in Cognitive Sciences, vol. 21, no. 3, pp. 182–194, Mar. 2017.</ref><ref>K. V. Sudakov, “The theory of functional systems: general postulates and principles of dynamic organization (dedicated to the Anokhin Centenary).,” Integr Physiol Behav Sci, vol. 32, no. 4, pp. 392–414, Dec. 1997.</ref>.
== Improving [[Adaptation]] in Athletes == The basis of Performance Medicine in improving [[athletic performance]] lies in the understanding that the functions of the [[immune system]], [[nervous system]], [[hormonal system]], and [[digestive system]] govern adaptation to training<ref>P. K. Anokhin, “Nodular Mechanism of Functional Systems as a Self-regulating Apparatus,” in Progress in Brain Research, vol. 22, E. A. Asratyan, Ed. Elsevier, 1968, pp. 230–251.</ref>. All environmental stimuli (including training and nutrition) are processed by these systems, which will respond with adaptation, if their capacity permits. It is therefore the functions of these systems, which determine the result of all training stimuli<ref>K. V. Sudakov, “The theory of functional systems: general postulates and principles of dynamic organization (dedicated to the Anokhin Centenary).,” Integr Physiol Behav Sci, vol. 32, no. 4, pp. 392–414, Dec. 1997.</ref><ref>C. W. Morris, “The Effect of Fluid Periodization on Athletic Performance Outcomes in American Football Players,” p. 110.</ref>.
Performance Medicine is to be clearly distinguished from sports science and sports coaching, which is mostly concerned with the optimal composition of training stimuli. In Performance Medicine the main concern is the functional status of the athlete's adaptive systems<ref>K. V. Sudakov, “The theory of functional systems: general postulates and principles of dynamic organization (dedicated to the Anokhin Centenary).,” Integr Physiol Behav Sci, vol. 32, no. 4, pp. 392–414, Dec. 1997.</ref>.
== See also == * [https://gerritkeferstein.com/2018/03/24/what-is-performance-medicine/ What is Performance Medicine]

{{Infobox horseraces |class = Group 3 |horse race = Prix de Guiche |image = |caption = |location = [[Chantilly Racecourse]]
[[Chantilly, Oise|Chantilly]], France |inaugurated = 1865 |race type = [[Flat racing|Flat]] / [[Thoroughbred]] |website = [http://www.france-galop.com/All-the-races.233+M52087573ab0.0.html?&course_id=1596&no_cache=1&numero_id=120 france-galop.com] |distance = 1,800 metres (1⅛ miles){{cite web|title=Prix de Guiche|url=http://www.thefrenchblacktype.com/race.html?speciality=&distance=&age=&sex=&category=group3&discipline=flat&id=17|website=The French Black Type|accessdate=9 May 2017}} |surface = Turf |track = Right-handed |qualification = Three-year-old [[Colt (horse)|colts]] |weight = 58 kg |purse = €80,000 ''(2018)''
'''1st:''' €40,000 }} The '''Prix de Guiche''' is a [[Group races|Group 3]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in [[France]] open to three-year-old [[thoroughbred]] [[Colt (horse)|colts]]. It is run over a distance of 1,800 metres (about 1⅛ miles) at [[Chantilly Racecourse|Chantilly]] in May. ==History== The event is named after [[Antoine-Geneviève-Héraclius-Agénor de Gramont|Antoine IX]] (1789–1855), the Duc de Guiche (and later [[Duke of Gramont|Duc de Gramont]]), who founded the successful Haras de Meudon stud farm. The Prix de Guiche was established in 1865, and it was originally held at [[Longchamp Racecourse|Longchamp]]. It was usually contested over 2,000 metres.{{cite web | title = 1868 Prix de Guiche | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5-UNAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA322&img=1&zoom=3&hl=en&sig=ACfU3U0UeISUSXOwCI7xRae-MMLAJHY11w&ci=37%2C250%2C483%2C247&edge=0 | work = Ruff's Guide to the Turf for 1869 | accessdate = 1 April 2013}} It was cancelled because of the [[Franco-Prussian War]] in 1871. It was run over 2,200 metres in 1873. The race was abandoned throughout World War I, with no running from 1915 to 1918. It was staged at [[Maisons-Laffitte Racecourse|Maisons-Laffitte]] in 1944 and 1945.{{cite news | title = Aujourd'hui à Maisons-Laffitte | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/proxy?method=R&ark=bpt6k5879961.f4&l=5&r=1484,1900,239,307 | newspaper = [[Le Matin (France)|Le Matin]] | date = 1 April 1944 | accessdate = 1 April 2013}} It was cut to 1,950 metres in 1953. With the exception of four editions over 1,850 metres (1963 and 1965–67), the event continued over 1,950 metres until 1986. It reverted to 1,850 metres in 1987. It was transferred to Chantilly and shortened to 1,800 metres in 2005. The Prix de Guiche can serve as a trial for the [[Prix du Jockey Club]]. Fifteen horses have won both races. The first was Consul in 1869, and the most recent was [[Almanzor (horse)|Almanzor]] in 2016. ==Records==
'''Leading [[jockey]] (8 wins):''' * [[Yves Saint-Martin]] – ''Relko (1963), Jour et Nuit (1964), White Star (1965), A Tempo (1966), Antipode (1974), Top Ville (1979), Shakapour (1980), Yashgan (1984)'' ---- '''Leading [[Horse trainer|trainer]] (9 wins):''' * Tom Jennings – ''Equivoque (1866), Pompier (1868), Consul (1869), Braconnier (1876), Saint Christophe (1877), Colifichet (1878), Barde (1879), Muscadin (1880), Gourgandin (1881)'' ---- '''Leading owner (9 wins):''' * Frédéric de Lagrange – ''Equivoque (1866), Pompier (1868), Consul (1869), Braconnier (1876), Saint Christophe (1877), Colifichet (1878), Barde (1879), Muscadin (1880), Gourgandin (1881)''

revision.text:
[[File:spaldeen.jpg|thumb|230px|Modern-day Spaldeen]] A '''Spalding Hi-Bounce Ball''', often called a '''Spaldeen''', is a rubber ball, the size of a [[tennis ball]] without the felt. It was the more expensive and more popular version of the Pensie Pinkie (made by [[Penn Racquet Sports]]). These balls are commonly used in [[street game]]s developed in the mid-20th century, such as [[Chinese handball]] (a variation on [[American handball]]), [[stoop ball]], hit-the-penny (involving trying to make a penny flip on a sidewalk), [[butts up]], [[handball (school)|handball]], [[punchball]], [[half-rubber]], and [[stickball]] (a variation of [[baseball]]).
==Name== The term arose from a [[New York City]]-accented pronunciation of [[Spalding (sports equipment)|Spalding]], the [[sporting goods]] company that produced the balls. The name has become so common that Spalding now uses it in marketing, and it is now a [[registered trademark]].<ref name="Dodgers">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/03/13/business/yourmoney/the-spaldeen-is-back-even-if-the-dodgers-arent.html|title=The Spaldeen Is Back (Even if the Dodgers Aren't)|date=13 March 2005|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
==History== Spaldeens were popular with children from the 1930s through to the 1970s. In [[urban area]]s sparse in grass, Spaldeens became integral to many street games due to their bounciness and light weight. Citing the declining popularity of stickball, Spalding took the ball off the market in 1979, but it returned in 1999 to much fanfare.<ref name="Dodgers" /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/05/05/nyregion/new-life-for-old-favorite-spaldeen-stickball-s-bouncy-foundation-makes-comeback.html|title=New Life for an Old Favorite; The Spaldeen, Stickball's Bouncy Foundation, Makes a Comeback|date=5 May 1999|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
==Colors== Since its return in 1999 Spaldeens have been manufactured in a variety of colors in addition to [[pink]]. Some of them are [[black]], [[blue]], [[green]], [[orange (color)|orange]], [[purple]], [[red]], and [[yellow]].
==See also== *[[Bouncing ball]] *[[Bouncy ball]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.spaldeen.com/ Spaldeen.com] (Spalding's promotional site for the ball)

{{About||the [[Gerry Anderson]] series|The Adventures of Twizzle}} {{for|The Nichols Cube Puzzle (Twizzle)|Larry D. Nichols}} {{Infobox Figure Skating Element |image= |imagesize= |caption= |element name= Twizzle |alt name= |scoring abbrev= STw |element type= |edges= |take off edge= |landing edge= |inventor= |named for= |disciplines= }} [[File:2011 TEB Free 188 Tessa Virtue Scott Moir.jpg|thumb|250px| 2010 and 2018 Olympic Gold Medalists [[Tessa Virtue]] and [[Scott Moir]] performing their free dance in 2012]] A '''twizzle''' is a multirotational one-foot turn in [[figure skating]].{{cite web|last=Eric|first=Freeman|title=What's a twizzle? Here's a guide to the figure skating term|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/olympics-fourth-place-medal/what-s-a-twizzle--here-s-a-guide-to-the-figure-skating-term-024737991.html|publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|accessdate=February 17, 2014}} The twizzle is most commonly seen in [[ice dancing]], where it appears in a number of [[Compulsory dance|Pattern Dances]] (originally called Compulsory Dance) and is a required element of step sequences in the [[short dance]], [[original dance]] and [[free dance (figure skating)|free dance]]. A twizzle is also common in [[synchronized skating]] where it is also a required element of step sequences. A twizzle differs from a [[Figure skating spins|figure skating spin]] in that it travels across the ice instead of being centered in one spot. Skaters can turn several revolutions on a twizzle, the number of which depends on the level at which they are skating or what is set in the specified steps of a Pattern Dance; as defined by the ISU Technical Committee of the relevant discipline. {{Cite web|title = What is the Difference Between Twizzles and Spins in Figure Skating?|url = http://figureskating.about.com/od/glossarylettert/g/twizzles.htm|accessdate = 2015-10-06|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150406130638/http://figureskating.about.com/od/glossarylettert/g/twizzles.htm|archivedate = 2015-04-06|df = }} Twizzles can be performed both forward and backward, on both inside and outside edges, and both clockwise and counterclockwise. Twizzles are most commonly performed in an upright position with the free foot held close to the skating leg, but other variants are possible as well, such as a twizzle in a [[sit spin]] position. Speed, ice coverage i.e. distance, unison (couples), closeness (couples), variety and difficulty of positions, change of rotational direction (counter-clockwise, clockwise), and difficult entries are taken into consideration by the judges and technical specialists. ==Gallery== File:2011 TEB Free 188 Tessa Virtue Scott Moir.jpg|Ice dance twizzle ([[Tessa Virtue]] & [[Scott Moir]]) Image:Kristine Musademba 2008-2009 JGPF.jpg|A twizzle in ladies singles skating
([[Kristine Musademba]]) Image:European 2011 Nathalie PECHALAT Fabian BOURZAT.jpg|Twizzles in ice dance
([[Nathalie Pechalat]] & [[Fabian Bourzat]]) Image:European 2011 Ekaterina BOBROVA Dmitri SOLOVIEV 3.jpg|Twizzles in ice dance
([[Ekaterina Bobrova]] & [[Dmitri Soloviev]]) Image:Junior World Championships 2008 Kristina GORSHKOVA Vitali BUTIKOV OD.jpg|Twizzles in ice dance
([[Kristina Gorshkova]] & [[Vitali Butikov]]) ==References== {{Commons category|Twizzles}} {{Figure skating}} [[Category:Figure skating elements]] {{Figure-skating-stub}} [[ru:Шаги в фигурном катании#Твизл]]

They play in the [[Congo Premier League]]. In 1971 the team has won the [[Congo Premier League]].http://www.rsssf.com/tablesk/kongchamp.html ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 13500 capacity [[Stade Municipal de Pointe-Noire]]. ==Honours== *'''[[Congo Premier League]]: 3''' :: 1971, 1998, 1999. *'''[[Coupe du Congo (Republic of Congo)|Coupe du Congo]]: 4''' :: 1974, 1977, 1996, 1997. *'''[[Super Coupe du Congo (Republic of Congo)|Super Coupe du Congo]]: 0''' ==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[CAF Champions League]]: 1appearance''' ::[[1971 African Cup of Champions Clubs]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Congo Premier League}} [[Category:Football clubs in the Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Pointe-Noire]] {{RCongo-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Workable | image = [[Image:Workable FC crest.png|150px|Workable FC crest]] | fullname = Workable Football Club | nickname = | founded = 2007 | dissolved = 2008 | ground = [[Mong Kok Stadium]]
[[Kowloon]], [[Hong Kong]] | capacity = 8,500 | chairman = {{flagicon|HKG}} [[Lam Hok Ling]] | manager = {{flagicon|HKG}} [[Chan Hiu Ming]] | league = [[Hong Kong First Division League|Hong Kong First Division]] | season = [[Hong Kong Second Division League 2006-07|2006–07]] | position = Second Division, 2nd | pattern_la1=_blueline |pattern_b1=_adidaslibero |pattern_ra1=_blueline |leftarm1=FFFF00 | body1=FFFF00 |rightarm1=FFFF00 |shorts1=0000FF |socks1=0000FF | pattern_la2=_whitelines |pattern_b2=_adidaslibero |pattern_ra2=_whitelines |leftarm2=0000FF | body2=0000FF |rightarm2=0000FF |shorts2=0000FF |socks2=0000FF }} '''Workable Football Club''' ({{zh|t=華家堡足球會}}) was a [[Hong Kong]] [[Association football|football]] club, played in [[Hong Kong First Division League]] in the 2007–08 season. ==History== The team got the 1st Runner-up in [[Hong Kong Third A Division League]] in 2005–06 season and qualified into [[Hong Kong Third Division League|Third Division League Final Round]] to fight for 2 promotion positions among 4 teams. Shek Kip Mei topped the table and was promoted to [[Hong Kong Second Division League|Second Division]]. After the promotion, the team added a few former-[[Hong Kong national football team]] players to strengthen the team for a further promotion to the [[Hong Kong First Division League|First Division]]. The team finished second in the second division in the 2006–07 season and has been promoted to the First Division League in 2007–08. After the promotion, the team obtained an [[HK$]]4,000,000 naming sponsorship from Workable Corporation and was named as Workable Football Club to compete in First Division League. The team released all the promotion heroes in Shek Kip Mei and obtained a few players from the extinct [[Hong Kong 08]] as the stem of team construction. They played its debut match in First Division League on 8 September 2007, drawing 2–2 with [[Wofoo Tai Po]] in [[Mong Kok Stadium]]. The match is also highlighted by that current Workable manager [[Chan Hiu Ming]] is the head coach of [[Wofoo Tai Po]] in the previous season. ==Sponsors== :{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- !Kit Manufacturer !Kit Sponsor |- |[[Adidas]] |[[Crocodile Garments]] |} ==External links== *{{zh icon}} [http://www.wkfc.com.hk wkfc.com.hk] Official website *[http://www.hkfa.com/en/team_list.php?club_id=35 Workable FC] at HKFA.com *{{zh icon}} [http://hk.myblog.yahoo.com/workable-fc Workable FC fan blog] [[Category:Defunct football clubs in Hong Kong]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 2007]] [[Category:2007 establishments in Hong Kong]] [[Category:2008 disestablishments in Hong Kong]] {{HongKong-footyclub-stub}}

== Zağnosspor == {{Infobox football club | clubname = Zağnosspor | image = ZagnosSK Logo.png | caption = Zağnosspor | fullname = Zağnos Spor Kulübü | nickname = | shortname = ZS | founded = 2014 | dissolved = | ground = 19 Mayıs Sports Hall, Yavuz Selim Stadium | capacity = | owner = Emre Aksoy | chrtitle = | chairman = Emre Aksoy | mgrtitle = | manager = Fatih Yılmaz | league = Turkish Women's Handball Super League,http://thf.gov.tr/tabid/174 Turkish Men's Handball Super League, Trabzon 1st Amateur Cluster http://www.amatorfutbol.org/askf/trabzon/super-amator/puandurumu-4302.html | season = | position = | website = http://zagnossporkulubu.com/ | fansgroup = | honours = }} {| class="infobox" style="font-size: 88%; width: 22em; text-align: center" ! colspan=3 style="font-size: 125%; background-color:red; color:blue; text-align: center" | Active branches of

(Men's) ! [[Zağnos SK (women's handball)|Handball
(Women's)]] |- ! [[File:Volleyball pictogram.svg|30px]] ! [[File:Boxing pictogram.svg|30px]] ! [[File:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px]] |- ! Volleyball ! Boxing ! Swimming |} '''Zağnosspor''' ({{lang-tr|Zağnos Spor Kulübü}}) is a [[multi-sports club]] established in [[Trabzon]], Turkey. The club is active in the branches football, men's and women's handball, volleyball, boxing and swimming. The club is named after [[Zağnos Pasha]] ({{lang-tr|Zağnos Paşa}} fl. 1446–1462 or 1469), who served as the [[sanjak-bey]] of the city following the conquest of Trabzon by the Ottoman Turks in 1461. Its colors are red, blue and white. Club president is '''Emre Aksoy'''. '''Aksoy''' is a well known businessman in Turkey and the Board Chairman of '''AKS Group Construction'''. http://www.aksgrupinsaat.com/ The club is best known for their [[Zağnos SK (women's handball)|women's handball team]] playing in the [[Turkish Women's Handball Super League]]. ==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |url=http://zagnossporkulubu.com/ |publisher=Zağnos Spor Kulübü |title=Takımlar |language=Turkish |accessdate=2016-01-24 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.thf.gov.tr/ligler/bayanlar-super-lig |publisher=Türkiye Hentbol Federasyonu |title=Ligler: Bayanlar Süper Lig |language=Turkish |accessdate=2016-01-24 }} {{cite news |url=http://takaonline.com/turkiye-zagnossporu-konusacak/ |newspaper=Taka |title=Türkiye Zağnosspor’u Konuşacak |date= |language=Turkish |accessdate=2016-01-24 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.zagnossporkulubu.com/haber/230/puanlar_paylasildi_26-26.html |publisher=Zağnos Spor Kulübü |title=Puanlar Paylaşıldı 26-26 |date=2016-01-06 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2016-01-24 }} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zagnos SK}} [[Category:Zağnos SK| ]] {{Turkey-sport-stub}}
